 ii Benefits and Risks: The project is expected to produce financial, social and economic benefits with regard to: (i) saved water and increased revenues by repairing and installing micro- and macro-meters, leakage repairs and reducing the amount of accounts receivable; (ii) improving drinking water and treated wastewater quality and thereby reducing health risks and environmental degradation; and (iii) improving service delivery, increasing per capita availability of drinking water, and extending connections to unserved populations. However, there are several risks related to implementing a project in the West Bank and Gaza (WBG), not all of which can be addressed at this point: (a) the potential for political instability, that could have several negative implications: (i) access obstruction due to border closure; and (ii) administrative difficulties to implement the Service Improvement Program by the Operator; (b) non-perforrnance of the Operator; and (c) lack of counterpart funds and less than anticipated income generation. The project is addressing these factors as follows: (a) political instability: all projects in WBG face political risks. The Peace Process has developed momentum and passed significant milestones, including Palestinian self-rule in Gaza and parts of the West Bank; nevertheless, disruptions due to political events can be expected from time to time and could delay implementation; (b) non-performance of the Operator: the Operator will work according to clearly defined and quantified performance criteria and will be compensated, in part, by a perforrnance incentive fee, built into the contract; and all sixteen municipalities and village councils have signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) attesting to their support for the project and agreeing to facilitate the work of the Operator; and (c) lack of counterpartfinds: the financial analysis has shown that current tariffs, combined with an increased sector efficiency, brought about by the Operator, will significantly improve financial performance. Poverty Category: The project is not a part of a core poverty program but is focused on Gaza where poverty is most acute. It will have a beneficial impact on poor households which are sometimes forced to purchase water from vendors at relatively high prices during service interruptions. Improvement of the quality of the water and improved sanitation will have a positive impact on reduction of gastro-enteric and other water-related diseases, which most often affect the poor. BACKGROUND 1.1 The combined area of the West Bank and Gaza (WBG) is approximately 6,000 square kilometers. The 1994 estimated combined population was about 2.4 million, of which 38 percent reside in the Gaza Strip. With its extremely dense population of 2,225 persons per square kilometer, the Gaza Strip has only 16 towns and villages. Registered refugees represent 72 percent of its population, of which about 50 percent live in refugee camps. The WBG has a per capita Gross National Product (GNP) of US$1,453 (1994), with a marked discrepancy in incomes between Gaza ($857) and the West Bank ($1,819). Estimates for 1995 suggest real Gross Domestic Product (GDP) growth of 3.5 percent, but due to further loss in employment opportunities for Palestinian workers in Israel', and allowing for population increase, real per capita GNP declined by an estimated 8 percent. Also, the already high 20 percent unemployment rate in 1994 is estimated to have risen to 25 percent. This indicates that the positive job creation performance, particularly in residential construction, was insufficient to overcome the impact of repeated Israeli border closures. The prospects for 1996 had appeared somewhat more promising until the recent bombings in Israel. These have led to extended border closings which have had a severely negative impact on economic and social life. Unemployment is now at crisis levels, particularly in Gaza. GDP and GNP in WBG are projected to decline by -11 and -17 percent, respectively, in real terms for 1996 as a whole. 1.2 The Interim Agreement signed between the Palestine Liberation Organization (PLO) and the Government of the State of Israel on September 28, 1995, restates parts of the Agreement on the Gaza Strip and Jericho Area signed in May 1994, and of the Agreement on Preparatory Transfer of Powers and Responsibilities (Cairo Agreement), signed in August 1994, and in so doing, supersedes the latter two agreements. Under the Interim Agreement, increasing responsibility has been granted to the Palestinian Council for public services in WBG, including the power to operate, manage and develop water and sewerage systems and resources. However, the existing systems supplying water to the Settlements and the Military Installation Area, and the water system and resources inside them continue to be operated and managed by the Israeli Mekoroth Water Company (Mekoroth). 1.3 The situation of the water sector is critical in both the West Bank and in Gaza. However, the extreme water resources limitations facing Gaza, possibly one of the most serious in the world today, demand a much better level of water resources management and greatly improved standard of service delivery to be achieved, and quickly. Groundwater, the only significant available source of water, is seriously over-utilized and badly contaminated. 1.4 There is an urgent need to complete the rehabilitation programn which has started under the Emergency Rehabilitation Project (ERP) and other bilateral donors' initiatives. The Executive Authority of the Palestinian Council (EAPC) places a high priority on the improvement of water and wastewater services in Gaza. A number of donor-supported investment and technical assistance projects are already underway in Gaza in order to: (a) extend the provision of water; (b) improve sewage collection and disposal facilities; (c) provide a healthy and clean environment for Gaza's inhabitants; and (d) attract the 1/ About 63,000 job opportunities were lost between 1992 and 1994, and another 29,000 in 1995.

THE WATER SUPPLY AND SANITATION SECTOR A. Water Resources 2.1 Almost the sole source of water in Gaza is the shallow aquifer that underlies the whole Gaza Strip and extends north into Israel. Accurate data is generally not available and estimates of abstractions and recharge vary considerably. There is agreement, however, that recharge is in the order of 60 million cubic meters (MCM) per year and is greatly exceeded by abstractions estimated at more than 130 MCM per year. Consequently, the water table is falling and quality is deteriorating as a result of both over- abstraction, which causes seawater intrusion and up-coning of deeper saline water, and contamination by seepage of pollutants from the surface, particularly from cesspits and septic tanks. Salinity and nitrates now exceed recommended standards for potable purposes over most of the Gaza Strip and agricultural use is increasingly affected by high salinity. Municipal water allocation from the Gaza aquifer accounts for only 30-35 MCM per year and is obtained from approximately 50 wells. An additional small quantity of currently 6.2 MCM is purchased from Mekoroth to supply areas where groundwater salinity is excessive. 2.2 There are no ready solutions to the water shortage and quality problems. Total annually renewable water resources are less than 70 cubic meters per capita, a level that constraints economic productivity. Limited quantities are available for purchase from Israel but at a price that is relatively expensive, even for municipal use. Alternatives such as desalination and importation, even from the West Bank, would also be expensive and require many years to implement. The conclusion is that the Palestinians of Gaza must primarily rely on better use and management of their own water resources rather than look for external solutions. Improved institutional capacity will be needed for both regulation and provision of services from these resources. 2.3 Furthermore, due to expected improved network efficiency, the current effective per capita use (water actually delivered to households and industries) of about 70 liters per day is expected to increase with this project by about 35 percent. Under the September 28, 1996 Interim Agreement, Gaza is also entitled to receive 5 MCM per year of additional water from Mekoroth (at a proposed cost of US$0.46 per cubic meter). This will help to maintain the current level of supply as the population increases, estimated at present at 6.2 percent per annum, gradually decreasing to 3.5 percent over the next ten years.2 Even though these changes, developments and additional supplies are far from sufficient to cover unmet demand for municipal water, the improvements resulting from the project will progressively increase sector revenues and put it on a path toward financial viability, which, in the long rnn, may allow exploration of more expensive, alternative water resources. These restrictions were not enforced in the weeks preceding and subsequent to the handover of responsibilities, and illegal wells proliferated. The Water Department was placed under the Ministry of Agriculture when it was established, but responsibility for regulatory matters in the water sector will be transferred to the newly created Palestinian Water Authority (PWA). The PWA was established by Decree 90/1995 in April 1995, and its powers and responsibilities defined in Bylaws (Law No 18/1996) enacted on January 18, 1996. The PWA has policy-making and regulatory responsibilities for both Gaza and the West Bank. Its authority in the West Bank is limited under the Interim Agreement pending final negotiations of the Israeli-Palestinian Peace Agreement. C. Sector Issues and Constraints 2.5 The present fragmented institutional structure in Gaza, with responsibility divided between 4 municipal water departments, 12 village councils, and a United Nations agency, is incompatible with efficient service delivery and the integrated management of the limited groundwater resources. The key sector challenges are: (a) improving water resource management and environmental health conditions, particularly management of the Gaza aquifer; (b) improving water supply delivery systems; (c) improving the sewerage collection, treatment and disposal system; (d) improving wastewater resource management; and (e) strengthening the institutional, financial and regulatory framework for the management of water and wastewater. 2.6 WaterAvailability, Aquifer Overdraft and Allocation. Limited renewable water resources is the main constraint for economic development in Gaza. Renewable water, all from underground resources, is less than 70 cubic meters per capita per year, amnong the lowest in the world. Present water use in Gaza currently is more than double the annually renewable supply of water. An additional 6.2 MCM per year is purchased from Mekoroth to supply central and southern communities. Of the cumulative total of about 136 MCM (pumped from the Gaza aquifer and purchased from Mekoroth), about 70 percent is used for agricultural irrigation. Of the balance, about half is unaccounted for and the remainder is used for commercial and industrial purposes (estimated at about 6-7 MCM per year) and for domestic use (about 15 MCM per year). 2.7 Unaccountedfor Water. Approximately 650 miles of transmission and distribution mains provide service to nearly 75,000 metered connections (there are also around 20,000 unmetered and illegal connections). Neither the volume of water produced nor used is recorded with any accuracy. Although most wells in Gaza and many consumers do have meters, many do not function, so that water pumped and used can only be estimated. However, overall estimates indicate that about 50 percent of water in municipal distribution networks is lost through leakages in distribution networks, illegal connections and inaccurate, or lack of metering. In summary, the average Gaza citizen has less than 70 liters per capita per day at disposal from public water supply, a low consumption in comparison to countries with similar income levels which typically use 80-120 liters per capita per day. 2.8 Water Use in Agriculture Although water conserving drip irrigation and plastic houses are known and occasionally used, most crops are still flood irrigated, an inefficient use, since only about 30 percent of the water reaches the plant. The rest evaporates, or ends up as agriculture run-off or drainage water, infiltrating through the soil into the shallow aquifers. The excessive water use in agriculture is partly a result of the lack of control over the drilling of wells. Although theoretically a license from the Ministry of Agriculture is necessary, it is estimated that at least 3,000 wells, of which about 1,000 are illegal, have been drilled in the past 20 years in the Gaza Strip.

The rest of the population uses septic tanks, pit latrines and other on-site excreta and wastewater disposal systems. The three operational treatment plants are inefficient (Jabalya, Gaza City and Rafah) and dispose of their insufficiently treated effluent either into the sea (without sea- outfall) or in open fields, causing coastal and aquifer pollution. For example, the effluent of the Jabalya treatment plant is a serious hazard for the still relatively unpolluted northem aquifer. New sewerage systems are expensive with a per capita cost of up to US$400--which corresponds to about US$3,000- 4,000 per household. At this cost, full sewerage coverage is unaffordable. In addition, none of the municipalities currently operating sewerage systems are able to fully recover Operation and Maintenance (O&M) expenses from users. There is no capital cost recovery. 2.10 Water Quality. The tremendous overdraft from shallow aquifers has serious implications. Not only are these resources finite and will eventually be exhausted, but the excessive withdrawals are causing seawater intrusion and up-coning of deeper brackish water. The salinity of most groundwater in Gaza, except for small areas in the north (6 MCM renewable) and south (3.5 MCM renewable) of the Gaza Strip, exceeds by up to five times the maximum norm indicated by the World Health Organization. Agricultural drainage water and leachate from sanitation facilities are the cause of high nitrate contents in aquifers. 2.11 Cost Recovery. Data related to cost recovery is limited. In addition to inaccurate water metering, there is no accounting separation between different operational departments in the 16 municipalities and village councils. While it is possible to discern the revenues from water and wastewater services, the costs incurred by these services cannot be clearly identified, as many functions are shared between different departments. Accounts receivable at any given time are estimated at 32 percent, based on 1994 figures and estimates. Overall, the 1994 financial deficit is estimated at only 2 percent, indicating that O&M costs could be covered with present tariffs, if the collection rate could be improved significantly (see Section VII "Financial Analysis"). However, maintenance expenditures are far below a level necessary to maintain infrastructure adequately, and no provision is made for depreciation or capital cost recovery. 2.12 Tariffs. The 16 communities have twelve different tariff systems. Most tariffs are flat or regressive and do not encourage conservation. Many municipalities and villages have large "social" blocks, allowing water use of up to 20 or 30 cubic meters per month without variation in price. The average tariff is between US$0.30 and US$0.40 per cubic meter. About 75 percent of all municipal water is used by Gaza City, Jabalya, Deir al Balah, Khan Younis and Rafah. Their average tariff is about US$0.20 to US$0.30 per cubic meter (see Section VII "Financial Analysis"). D. Sector Investment Program 2.13 At this very early stage of Palestinian empowerment, planning of sector investments is still at a very preliminary stage. Little investment took place during the period of military occupation although the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) and United Nations Relief and Works Agency (UNRWA) made important contributions and facilitated other donor funding for priority projects. The Emergency Assistance Program (EAP) prepared in December 1993 defined a strategy for the sector with initial investment priority given to: rehabilitation and selective extension of municipal and village water networks; construction of new wells in selected municipalities and villages where resource, institutional and political conditions permit; urgently needed tools and equipment to support improved O&M; the development of the Jerusalem Water Undertaking (JWU) as a model regional utility; and rehabilitation and extension of existing sewerage networks and treatment plants. These priorities have been supported during the first two years by the ERP through the Palestinian Economic Council for Development and

A rapid review of water and sanitation requirements with a 10-year horizon indicates that investment needs in Gaza alone are in the order of US$500 million. Detailed planning within the water sector is needed to define a sectoral investment program. This was not possible prior to the establishment of the PWA. It has been agreed that a Gaza and West Bank Water and Sanitation Planning Study will be implemented by the PWA, with funding provided by the Technical Assistance Trust Fund (TATF), as an immediate priority to define a five- to ten-year investment framework. Pending more detailed sectoral planning, the Bank/IDA has assisted the EAPC to define a Core Investment Program, including the proposed Water and Sanitation Services Project in Gaza and a Municipal Infrastructure Development Project which will include water sector investments in the West Bank. The Core Investment Program was presented to a Donors' Meeting in Paris in January 1996. In addition and in parallel to the Gaza project, which primarily addresses improvement of service operations, around US$60 million investment program of priority infrastructure rehabilitation and improvements in Gaza has been identified in conjunction with local governments. A number of bilaterally supported projects are addressing some of the larger infrastructure improvement needs. E. Sector Outlook 2.15 A future situation is envisaged in which management of the separate municipal and village council water and wastewater departments in Gaza would be consolidated into a single, efficient Water and Wastewater Company for Gaza (WWCG), administratively and financially independent of the local governments that it serves, but accountable to its customers to provide adequate supplies of water to meet their drinking and other water needs, and to collect wastewater for treatment and re-use. 2.16 The immedfate objective, however, is to improve to an acceptable level the quality of water supplied and wastewater treated, the quantity of water available, and the management of water and wastewater services. To do so, an internationally experienced water and wastewater operator would assist in implementing a service improvement program. The existing municipal and village council water and wastewater departments would be strengthened, operation and maintenance of services improved, and the management and financial accounting of water and wastewater services separated from other services. This is expected to lead to the establishment of WWCG, capturing economies of scale, and facilitating a more efficient, sustainable and equitable sharing of the limited available water resources. 2.17 Upon completion of the operator's contract, the fully functional unified WWCG is expected to continue to operate autonomously under the direction of a Board of Directors. If the EAPC so chooses, private sector management could be continued in the form of a management contract, affermage, or a concession granted to the private sector to provide water and wastewater services for an extended period of time. Sector Objectives 3.1 The short-term strategy for the water and wastewater sector in WBG is to: (a) improve the quantity of water and strengthen regulatory controls over the Gaza aquifer; institute effective conservation practices to reduce losses and manage demand; improve the quality and management of water; (b) involve the private sector in the provision and management of services; (c) continue to implement a program of priority water network rehabilitation and expand piped water coverage to selected municipalities and villages; implement a program of priority sewerage network and treatment plant rehabilitation; and develop new wells; (d) lay the basis for long-term institutional reform; (e) create regional water and wastewater companies by rationalizing and consolidating individual municipal utility departments and village councils; (f) establish effective data collection and cost recovery policies and systems; and (g) establish an effective regulatory framework. The medium- and long-term strategy is to: (a) develop and implement coherent water resources management policies for the West Bank and for Gaza, including particularly a wastewater re-use policy for Gaza; (b) develop regional water resources management policy with Jordan and Israel; (c) extend and consolidate a program of priority network rehabilitation; expand piped water coverage to all villages; (d) develop additional new wells in the context of an overall water resources management strategy; (e) consider desalination subject to economic feasibility; (f) develop and implement a long-term WBG-wide program of improvement to sewerage networks and treatment plants, and reclaimed water re- use; and (g) increase private sector participation in the provision of services. B. Palestinian Council's Water Policy 3.2 The PWA has a number of agreements relating to water resources contained in the Interim Agreement. These include management to prevent harm to the water resources, continued supply of water to Settlements and the Military Installation Area, and payment of the real cost of water purchased from Mekoroth. Law 18 of January 18, 1996 empowering the PWA to exercise its functions provides the overall direction of sectoral policy. The PWA presented IDA with a detailed statement of Flements of a Palestinian Water Policy. A key factor of the EAPC's water policy is the separation between regulatory functions and service delivery. The PWA will be in charge of regulation, comprising tariff review, water law and legislation, water extraction licensing and monitoring, overall sector planning and coordination, and establishing standards for drinking water and wastewater quality, as well as other technical standards. 3.3 The legislation also establishes a Water Council to make decisions on sectoral policy, water management, tariffs, and key organizational arrangements. The Water Council comprises representatives of relevant ministries and research institutions. The role, mandate, scope of work and powers of the PWA and its commissioner are defined in the legislation. 3.4 Water ResourcesPlanning/lInstitutionalStudy. During the first year of the project, the PWA will carry out a Water Resources Planning/Institutional Study for the WBG, financed by the TATF, and managed by IDA. The objectives of this study would be to formulate a vision for the water sector; contribute to sector policy development and water resources strategy; develop plans for optimal use of water allocations in accordance with the provision of Article 40 (Water and Sewage) of the Interim Agreement; determine priority investments and estimate costs for a five- to ten-year investment program; and assist to define a more appropriate institutional framework for service delivery.

The New Institutional Framework 3.5 As indicated in previous sections, it is expected that in the future, water and sewerage responsibilities in WBG will be merged into a small number of regional utility companies along similar lines to the JWU in the Ramallah District. In Gaza a single company (WWCG) is envisaged. However, in the short term, service provision in Gaza will remain the responsibility of municipalities and village councils and a Management Contract Operator (Operator) will implement a Service Improvement Program. 3.6 The above policy has been agreed to by all municipalities, village councils in Gaza and the PWA and translated into a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) signed by all parties. It states that the municipalities and village councils support the proposed Service Improvement Program and are willing to cooperate and facilitate the assistance to be provided by an Operator. The municipalities and village councils will also maintain, as a minimum, present operating levels and financing of water supply and sanitation in their respective areas including staff, power and consumables. Moreover, they support in principle the proposed WWCG, the form of which has yet to be determined and agreed; and they will collaborate and cooperate fully with the Operator to facilitate necessary preparatory activities that will be required in order to make a decision to proceed with the establishment of WWCG. 3.7 Implementation of the Management Contract would be facilitated by a Steering Committee (SC), which was recently established and could subsequently become the Board of the WWCG. It comprises representatives of the municipalities and village councils, consumers, the PWA, and appropriate ministries of the EAPC. VII. FINANCIAL ANALYSIS A. Current Situation 7.1 Quality of Data. The availability of data in the Gaza Strip, both operational and financial, is poor. On the operational side, neither water produced nor used is recorded with any accuracy. Although most wells have meters, they often do not work, and water production can only be estimated. Similarly, water use is in many cases not measured, due to defective meters. It is also estimated that throughout Gaza, there are more than 20,000 illegal connections, but the amount of water "lost" through these connections is not known. Overall, unaccounted-for water in the municipal distribution system is in the order of 50 percent, including through network leakages, illegal connections and inaccurate metering. 7.2 On financial data, none of the 16 municipalities and village councils keep records of the assets they own, nor do they publish financial statements related to income and expenditures of the sector. While all communities have separate departments for water and sanitation, accounts are not strictly kept apart from other municipal or village activities. Although income from water and sanitation services can be identified, the cost arising from those services can only be estimated, since in many cases, municipal functions and tasks are shared between different services. Annex 7, Table 7.1, provides Comparative Statistical Data for all of the Gaza Strip, as well as for individual municipalities and village councils. 7.3 Tariffs. The 16 municipalities and village councils have twelve different tariff systems. Many of them depict flat, or regressive tariffs, not encouraging conservation. Water tariffs range between

This compares with total operating costs of US$0.31 per cubic meter. However, maintenance expenditures are minimal and capital costs are not recovered. Water sales from Mekoroth average NIS 1.29 per cubic meter (US$0.43). Hence, tariffs in Khan Younis and the surrounding central and southern Gaza villages, where mostly Mekoroth water is used, are the highest. Tariffs in this area range from US$0.33 per cubic meter for up to 20 cubic meters in Khan Younis, to US$0.66 per cubic meter for the highest consumption block (30 and above cubic meters per month) in Bani Suheila, Abassan K, Abassan S and Khzaa (Annex 7, Table 7.2--Domestic Tariffs for Gaza, October 1995). 7.4 Only the four municipalities and the village council of Beit Lahia and Jabalya, where some sewerage is in place, collect a small sewerage charge. The sewerage tariff, covering about half of sewerage costs, is typically added to the water bill. For example, Jabalya has 2,970 sewerage connections, about 65 percent of the households connected to the drinking water distribution network. The sewerage charge is US$1.65 per month, which resulted in an operating loss for sewerage of US$60,000 in 1994. Gaza City has 20,000 sewerage connections and a sewerage charge of 15 percent of the water tariff, resulting in 1994 in an operating loss of US$173,000. The overall operating cash loss for sewerage in Gaza Strip is US$630,000, again with minimal expenditure on maintenance and no capital cost recovery. 7.5 Revenues and Operating Expenses. Tariff Collection is weak due to poverty, poor service and the legacy of the occupation. Accounts receivable range between 32 percent and 40 percent. In 1994, this resulted in a revenue shortfall (difference between billing and collection) of about US$2.5 million. The overall water and sewerage operating loss in the Gaza Strip in 1994 is estimated at US$107,000. (Annex 7, Table 7.3--Gaza Strip, Statement of Revenues and Operating Expenses). However, it should be noted that expenditure on maintenance was far below an acceptable level because of lack of funds. The Operator is expected to introduce a uniforn billing and collecting system and mechanisms for non- payment of bills. These measures, along with improved service delivery, are the cornerstones to improved tariff collection. B. Financial Outlook 7.6 Under the proposed project, about 15,000 illegal water connections out of an estimated 20,000 are expected to be legalized, around 20,000 defective consumer connections replaced, between 20,000 and 50,000 faulty meters replaced or repaired, unaccounted-for water reduced from 48 percent to 30 percent, and accounts receivable reduced from 32 percent to 10 percent. At the end of the four-year Management Contract, annual revenues collected are expected to increase by almost 50 percent (about US$2.5 million). Due to an efficiency increase, and given the current tariff structure and consumption pattern, operating costs would fall from US$5.5 million to US$4.5 million per year. Overall improvements would result in an operating cash surplus of US$3.5 million--a dramatic increase from a loss of US$107,000 before implementation of the management contract (Annex 7, Table 7.4--Impact of Management Contract on Income and Expenditure). Annex 8 provides details of the Financial Analysis. 7.7 In summary, the above results can be achieved without an increase in tariffs, other than cost of living adjustments. It is, however, expected that the Operator, in agreement with the municipalities and the village councils, will restructure the tariff system from its current flat or regressive stage to a progressive scale and to increase sewerage charges. As services improve and willingness to pay (WTP) increases, tariffs can be raised to encourage conservation of scarce water resources and to progressively increase the recovery of capital expenditures.

It constitutes an urgent measure to quickly improve the dismal drinking and wastewater situation in the Gaza Strip, thereby reducing health hazards and environmental degradation, and improving economic opportunities. 8.2 The project is designed to improve the quantity, quality and management of the water and wastewater sector. Specifically, at the end of the four-year project period: (i) the Gaza water sector will have at least 65,000 newly regularized service connections; (ii) effective water use will increase by about 20 percent to 58 liters per capita per day; (iii) water will be reliably disinfected throughout Gaza; and (iv) the quality of wastewater discharges will be significantly improved. 8.3 In addition, the Management Contract will improve overall water resources management in Gaza, mainly through an increase in sector efficiency (reduction of unaccounted-for water), improved planning and project design capacity within the municipalities and village councils, and through implementation of a uniform, progressive tariff system throughout Gaza to encourage water conservation and recovery of full operation and maintenance costs, as well as an increasing portion of capital costs. 8.4 The proposed project will produce social, economic and environmental benefits with regard to: (i) saved water and increased revenues by repairing and installing consumer and production meters, leakage repairs, regularizing illegal connections, reducing the amount of accounts receivable, and by economies of scale achieved by the consolidation of services under a single WWCG; (ii) improving drinking and wastewater quality, consequently reducing health risks and environmental degradation; (iii) improving service delivery, increasing per capita availability of drinking water, and extending connections to unserved populations; (iv) protecting the environment, particularly aquifers from wastewater pollution and seawater intrusion; (v) creating employment during implementation of the Service Improvement Program; and (vi) improving economic opportunities and quality of life for the Gaza population in general. The project would also help strengthen the PWA, local municipal and village council water departments, and create a sustainable service delivery through the envisaged WWCG. Finally, the project will assist the EAPC in the management of a vital resource, and thereby contribute to the Peace Process. B. Economic Benefits 8.5 Many of the above benefits are not quantifiable and will have repercussions beyond the water sector. The analysis of quantifiable benefits shows an economic rate of return (ERR) of about 14 percent, ten years after project completion. This compares with an opportunity cost of capital of about 10 percent in countries with similar income levels (e.g., Jordan, 8.5 percent; Egypt, 12 percent). 8.6 The underlying assumptions for this analysis are that: (i) the Operator will achieve sector efficiency targets as spelled out in Annex 9 (reduction in unaccounted-for water); (ii) given finite and already vastly over-exploited water resources within Gaza, future new supplies from traditional resources will increase only marginally; (iii) population growth, currently at 6.2 percent per year (mostly from refugees and immigration), will decline to about 3.5 percent in ten years; (iv) given the large unmet municipal demand and the extreme pressure in general on water resources in the Middle East Region-- resulting in high water prices in the West Bank and in comparable neighboring countries--the WTP is

Although achieving a sector efficiency improvement from currently 52 percent to 70 percent in four years may appear optimistic in the Gaza context, a one-year delay in meeting distribution network efficiency targets would only marginally affect the ERR. This is explained by the large unmet municipal demand, expected to be about 75 percent higher than effective water use with the project ten years from now (Annex 8, Table 8.4). In comparable countries in the Middle East, water is frequently purchased from vendors at prices ranging from US$3 (Lebanon) to US$5 (Jordan) per cubic meter. 8.8 Water for agricultural use is currently virtually free. Tariffs are non-existent. License fees for wells are nominal and are often not collected. At least 1,000 out of approximately 3,000 wells are illegal. In some cases, mostly in the central area of Gaza, where water is especially scarce, farmers sell their excess water to nearby municipalities, at prices of up to US$0.70 per cubic meter, despite nitrate contamination and high salinity. To relieve the scarcity constraint on alternative, higher value-added economic development for resource conservation and equity, it is likely that agriculture will have to give up water for the benefit of municipal supplies. Thus, a system for charging for agricultural water will have to be established. This will allow shifting water from low-value crops to higher-value uses. Based on experience in countries of similar economic development, potential municipal per capita demand in Gaza would be 80 to 120 liters per day, between 33 and 44 cubic meters per year. It is estimated that within the next eight to ten years, per capita demand for municipal water will increase to about 60 cubic meters per year (see Annex 8). Scarcity of water resources and the unsustainable use of groundwater are the major environmental issues in Gaza. Groundwater abstractions conisiderably exceed recharge, regulatory control over the drilling of wells and abstractions of water are ineffective, and contamination of the shallow aquifer has resulted from over-use, inadequate sanitation, and inappropriate agricultural activities. 2. At present the aquifer underlivng Gaza, the only significant water resource, is overdrawn by at least 100% in excess of the average annual recharge. The main use, for agricultural irrigation, is ineffectively controlled with a proliferation of illegal wells and no effective limits on abstractions from licensed wells. Fees are either not charged or not collected for a permit to drill a well, for an annual license to operate a well, or for the volume of water abstracted from a well. As a consequence, water levels have declined below sea level over a large area, and salinity, with the exception of limited and decreasing areas, significanly exceeds drinking water standards and is adversely affecting irrigated crops. Partly as a result of over-use of fertilizers, but particularly as a consequence of wastewater leaching into the aquifer from cesspits and wastewNiater treatment plants, the concentration of nitrates in groundwater also exceeds health guidelines, in some municipal wells by an order of magnitude. Furthermore, agricultural irrigation practices are inefficient and wasteful of water. 3. Although municipal and industrial water use is lower, its management also leaves much to be desired. Unaccounted-for losses are in the order of 50% of the quantity pumped into the system, and tariffs are too low to signiticantly encourage conservation or to provide sufficient revenue to finance adequate maintenance, resulting in further deterioration of assets and declining service. 4. Wastewater services are limited. Three houses out of four utilize cesspits which contaminate the groundwater, and sullage (grey water from washing, bathing, and kitchen water use) is usually discharged to surface drains and eventually pollutes wadis and low-lying areas. In those areas served by sewerage, lack of control over discharges from industries, opening of manholes to relieve stormwater flooding, and inadequate and poorly operated treatment plants, all result in poor service and environmental degradation. A particular case is the Beit Lahia Treatment Plant, where effluent is discharged into surrounding sand dunes, slowly accumulating in a large plume of poor quality water which is contaminating the aquifer containing the best quality groundwater remaining in Gaza. 5. The above problems result from many causes: the lack of attention during nearly three decades of military occupation, the absence of an adequate legal and institutional framework, the shortage of adequately qualified and trained staff, the lack of public awareness of the consequences of water use and behavior, and the lack of finan,dial resources needed to construct and maintain the needed infrastructure. This figure was derived as the average revenue per m3 for the councils of Bureij, Maghazi and Nuseirat, which are similar in character and tariff structure to the councils for which data was available. When not recorded, accounts receivable were assumed to be 40% of total revenue, which appeared consistent with other Village Councils. Mekoroth: When a council buys water from Mekoroth but the costs were not available, the volumes drawn (derived from the Lyonnaise des Eaux (LYSA) May 1995 report) were charged at 1.29 NIS/m3 (US$0.43/i3), the current tariff. * Unaccounted-for water: Figures for Beit Lahia and Jabalya Camp were not available. The key questions which the financial modelling was intended to answer were: How much revenue can be expected to be generated if the targets in the Management Contract are achieved, including the conversion of 15,000 illegal connections to legal ones, the reduction in unaccounted-for water to 30% and the reduction of accounts receivable to 10% by the end of four years? * In this improved financial situation, will the current tariffs for water and wastewater in Gaza be sufficient to cover the operation and maintenance costs of the network (taking into account that they are simply indexed with the cost of living)? Given the difficult economic situation in Gaza, substantial increases in the overall level of water tariffs in real terms are not expected in the next few years. Therefore, the ability of the system to finance its operating and maintenance costs from current revenues (at current tariff levels) is important for a unified water and wastewater utility to maintain the integrity of the supply system and to retain the benefits stemming from the Management Contract. Approach and Assumptions 15. Because of the limitations of the data, there is little purpose served in attempting to build a complex financial forecasting model for the water and wastewater sector in Gaza. Such a model would only serve to lend a spurious appearance of accuracy to financial figures which must at best be viewed as indicative of the true position. 16. The simple approach that has been adopted therefore is a comparison of two static positions, one presenting the current situation as represented by our estimates of the position of the sector for 1994, and the other representing a re-working of the 1994 figures taking into account the changes that will occur in all relevant cost and revenue items as a consequence of the successful implementation of the Management Contract. This has the benefit of isolating the specific impact of the Management Contract without attempting to project the additional effect of cost inflation and further population growth. 17. The main aspects of the Management Contract which have an impact on the finances of the sector are assumed to be as follows: Reduction in illegal connections by 15,000: This increases the volume of water for which the Municipalities and Village Councils can bill, leading to increased revenue. In addition, it is to be assumed that once illegal connections are placed on a meter they will reduce their use of the volume of water the utilities need to purchase from Mekoroth. For the purposes of modelling, the current average use per legal connection and per illegal connection in each area was applied. Consumption per illegal connection is typically at least 10% higher than per legal connection. On conversion of an illegal connection to a legal one a reduction in consumption to the average level in that area for legal connections was assumed.
 Annex 8 Page 6 of 15 * Reduction in leakage: This has a direct benefit to the water utilities in terms of reducing the volume of water that must be pumped or purchased from Mekoroth for a given level of consumption. * Meter repair and replacement: When connections with non-functional or poorly functioning meters have a new meter installed, an effect on the level of water use is expected because the connection will thereafter be paying for each cubic meter they use. The size of this effect is not easy to estimate. It was therefore assumed that new and repaired meters installed reduce consumption by 10% of the average consumption per connection in that area. * Reduction in accounts receivable: It was assumed that reducing accounts receivable has no impact on water use, only on receipts. However, it could be argued that reducing accounts receivable has a similar impact to installing functioning meters: connections that were previously not paying their bills will afterwards actually be paying for the water they use, and they may reduce their water use as a result. 18. The assessment of the financial impact of these changes was modelled using the following additional assumptions. * Impact on revenue: Each additional cubic meter supplied to a legal connection generates revenue at the average price per cubic meter currently applying in the relevant area. * Impact on receipts: Receipts are assumed to reach 90% of revenue, because the target for accounts receivable is 10%. * Impact on costs: This impact is extremely difficult to estimate. It was assumed that reductions in volume pumped as a result of reduced leakage and consumption per connection will lead to reductions in energy costs and the costs of purchasing from Mekoroth. No effect is assumed for materials costs because only a tiny fraction of these costs are -currently related to the use of chemicals. Part II: Methodology of Economic Analysis A. Social and Economic Justification 1. This project follows and complements the ERP. It constitutes an urgent measure to quickly improve the dismal drinking and wastewater situation in Gaza, thereby reducing health hazards and improving economic opportunities. Economic Sector Work is planned in 1996/1997, and it is anticipated that the water and sanitation sector will emerge as a priority for the future socio-economic development of Gaza, and that this project will match the criteria for actions to bring about quick results in this priority sector. 2. The project is expected to meet its objective to improve the quantity, quality and management of the water and wastewatersector. Specifically, and as a result of the project, it is expected that at the end of the four-year project period: (i) the Gaza water sector will have at least 65,000 newly regularized service connections (20,000 connections replaced; 30,000 meters replaced; and 15,000 illegal connections converted to legal status); (ii) effective water use would increase by about 20 percent to 58 liters per capita per day; (iii) water will be reliably disinfected throughout Gaza; and (iv) the quality of wastewater discharges will be significantly improved. 3. In addition, the Management Contract will improve overall water resources management in Gaza, mainly through an increase in sector efficiency (reduction of unaccounted-for water), a reduction of accounts receivable, improved planning and project design capacity within the municipalities and village councils, and through implementation of a uniform, progressive tariff system throughout Gaza to encourage water conservation and recovery of full operation and maintenance costs, as well as an increasing portion of capital costs. 4. The proposed project will produce social, economic, financial and environmental benefits with regard to: (i) saved water and increased revenues by repairing and installing consumer and production meters, leakage repairs, regularizing illegal connections, reducing the amount of accounts receivable, and by economies of scale achieved by the consolidation of services under a single WWCG; (ii) improving drinking and wastewater quality, consequently reducing health risks; (iii) improving service delivery, increasing per capita availability of drinking water, and extending connections to unserved populations; (iv) protecting the environment, particularly aquifers, from wastewater pollution; (v) creating employment during implementation of the Service Improvement Program; and (vi) improving economic opportunities and quality of life for the Gaza populh'ioni in general. The project would also help strengthen the PWA, local municipal water departments and create a sustainable service delivery through the envisaged WWCG. Finally, the project will assist the EAPC to achieve autonomy in the management of a vital resource, and thereby contribute to the Peace Process.
 Annex 8 Page 8 of 15 B. Economic Benefits 5. Many of the above benefits are not quantifiable and will have repercussions beyond the water sector. The analysis of quantifiable benefits shows an economic rate of return (ERR) of about 14 percent, ten years after project conclusion. This compares with an opportunity cost of about 10 percent in countries at similar income levels (e.g., Jordan, 8.5 percent; Egypt, 11 percent). 6. The underlying assumptions for this analysis are that: (i) the Operator will achieve maximum sector efficiency targets (reduction in unaccounted-for water); (ii) given finite and already vastly over- exploited water resources within Gaza, future new supplies from traditional resources will increase only marginally; (iii) population growth, currently at 5 percent per year (mostly from refugees and immigration), will decline and level off to about 2.8 percent in ten years; (iv) given the large unmet municipal demand and the extreme pressure in general on water resources in the Middle East Region-- resulting in high water prices in comparable neighboring countries--the willingness to pay (WTP) is assumed to be higher than the present highest block tariff in Gaza (US$0.67 per cubic meter), gradually increasing over ten years to the cost of supply from desalination, by then projected at US$1.25 per cubic meter. The paragraphs below provide details on the key assumptions. 7. These are conservative estimates. Although achieving a sector efficiency improvement from currently 52 percent to 70 percent in four years may appear optimistic in the Gaza context, a one-year delay in meeting distribution network efficiency targets would only marginally affect the ERR. Other assumptions were deliberately under-rated, given current uncertainties in Gaza. Similarly, they would have only minor impacts on the ERR. This is explained by the large unmet municipal demand (at present close to 100 percent of effective water use), resulting in a WTP factor which is probably significantly higher than the highest tariff block in Gaza which is US$0.67 per cubic meter. In the West Bank, the highest tariff block is equivalent to US$1.45 per cubic meter. In comparable countries in the Middle East, water is purchased from vendors at prices ranging from US$3 (Lebanon) and US$5 (Jordan) per cubic meter. 8. Water for agricultural use is currently virtually free. Tariffs are nonexistent. License fees for wells are nominal and are often not collected. At least 1,000 out of approximately 3,000 wells are illegal. In many cases, especially in the central area of Gaza, where water is especially scarce, farmers sell their excess water to nearby municipalities, at prices of up to US$0.70 per cubic meter, despite nitrate contamination and high salinity. To relieve the scarcity constraint on alternative, higher value-added economic development, for resource conservation and equity, agriculture should give up water for the benefit of municipal supplies. This would require that a system for charging for agricultural water will have to be established to encourage shifting water from low-value crops to higher-value uses. Likewise, municipal tariffs--at present on average US$0.33 per cubic meter--would have to be increased to allow recovery of the full cost for operation and maintenance and, gradually, also capital expenditures. 9. Sensitivity analyses have been carried out with four alternative scenarios: ERR 10 years (after project execution) (i) Total benefits increased by 10 percent 15 % (ii) Total benefits decreased by 10 percent 13 %

Water Demand Versus Supply. The current per capita municipal consumption (domestic and industrial use) of about 70 liters per day (24 cubic meters per year)--one of the lowest in the world--is a constraint on socio-economic growth. Based on experience in countries of similar economic development, potential per capita municipal demand in Gaza would be at least 80 to 120 liters per day, between 33 and 44 cubic meters per year. This demand will increase, both with population growth and with economic development. It is estimated that within the next eight to ten years, per capita demand for municipal water will increase to about 60 cubic meters per year (Table 8.3). The savings resulting from improving distribution network efficiency and from expected additional supplies from Israel, would increase per capita availability of water to about 33 cubic meters per capita per year, while total per capita annual municipal demand will be about 60 cubic meters. This would leave an enormous gap in unmet demand (Figure 1). The following explains the meaning of major terms used throughout this analysis and the rationale underlying the key assumptions used to assess social and economic benefits: (a) Municipal Water Supply includes domestic and industrial water. In 1995, an estimated 43.0 MCM were pumped into the water supply network of the 16 municipalities and village councils. Approximately 36.8 MCM were extracted from aquifers and 6.2 MCM were supplied by Israel from Mekoroth. The 1995 figures were used as a basis for estimates projected into the future. Supplies are from aquifer withdrawals and from Israel, including an additional 5 MCM as per the September 28, 1995 Interim Agreement (Table 8.3). They are projected to increase in parallel with population growth. (b) Population Growth has been extremely high in the past, among the highest in the world. This is mostly the result of the return of refugees and immigration. For the purposes of this analysis, it is estimated that the population growth rate would gradually decrease over the next ten years from 6.2 percent in 1995 to 3.5 percent by 2004, declining to about 2.7 percent by 2012.2 The Gaza land area is limited and has already one of the highest population densities in the world (less than 10 mZ per person in some refugee camps). The territory will, thus, reach a level of saturation, both in population density and in economic opportunities (Table 8.3). (c) Willingness to pay is perceived to be relatively high in Gaza, mainly as a result of the large unmet demand and finite resources. The highest block tariff in the central villages of Gaza is at present US$0.67 per cubic meter. The highest block tariff in the Ramallah District of the West Bank is US$1.45 per cubic meter. Table 7.1 provides data on average price per cubic meters consumed in each municipality and village council in Gaza. In comparable neighboring countries the price for water from vendors (tank trucks) is US$5 (Jordan) and US$3 (Lebanon) per cubic meter. Another comparator was GDP in the West Bank and in Gaza. The latter is 60 percent of the former; thus, it was assumed that given the much more acute water shortage in Gaza, the WTP in Gaza would be about 60 percent of the highest block tariff in the West Bank, i.e., US$0.80 per cubic meter in 1996. The WTP factor would gradually increase to reach in 2001 the projected price of desalinated water, US$1.25 per cubic meter delivered through the distribution network. It would then remain constant, as supplies at this price will be unlimited (Tables 8.3 to 8.6). (d) Cost savings from increased operational efficiency are based on findings of the financial analysis in Part I, estimating that at project completion the Operator would achieve savings in operating costs of about US$1 million per year. It was assumed that these savings would marginally increase over a ten-year period after project completion, to reach US$2.5 million in 2009. doc.abstracts: The Water and Sanitation Services Project in Gaza will address urgent priorities aimed at improving the quality, quantity and management of water and wastewater services in Gaza. The project will assist the Executive Authority of the Palestinian Council in meeting urgent needs through: 1) improving water and sanitation services through a private sector management contract for water and wastewater operations; 2) strengthening and restructuring the institutional framework for both service delivery and sector governance functions; and 3) creating the operational, institutional and managerial conditions for priority rehabilitation, upgrading and extension projects to be financed by donors. The project will consist of the following components: 1) management contract fees; 2) operating investment; and 3) technical assistance and institutional capacity development.
